text:
-Today on TimesCast, President
Obama travels to New York to

visit Ground Zero for the
first time as president.

The photographer Doug Mills, who
was with President Obama

today, reflects on the
last time he was at
Ground Zero in 2001.

-It's a far different scene from
the last time I was here.
[CROWD CELEBRATION]

-And social scientists explain
the celebratory reaction to
Osama bin Laden's death.

-President Obama traveled to New
York today to lay a wreath

at Ground Zero, the site
of the 9/11 attacks.

This came six days after he
ordered the night-time raid in

Pakistan that killed Osama
bin Laden, the
mastermind of those attacks.

The wreath ceremony itself was
somber and hushed, and the

president did not deliver
any major remarks.

One of the questions raised
today was why this was the

first time President Obama had
traveled to Ground Zero since
entering the White House.

He'd been there before as a
candidate, but not since
becoming president.

The White House says that the
president would have come

anyway in a few months for the
10th anniversary of 9/11 and
will still do so.

And they also said he's been
preoccupied for the past
couple of years.

And in any event, the Obama
administration has made

Afghanistan a priority in
a way that the Bush

administration didn't do for
the last several years.

The administration has made much
of the fact the killing

bin Laden does not erase the
threat from Al Qaeda and that

it's necessary to continue the
war effort in Afghanistan.

Still, for the families of the
victims, there is a feeling of

closure as they meet with
President Obama
today in New York.
[AIRPLANE NOISE]

-This is Doug Mills,
photographer with the New York

Times, traveling with President
Obama today.
[AIRPLANE NOISE]
[HELICOPTER NOISE]

-Today's emotions were
very somber.

Very little remarks
by the president.

-These two, right here, can
be right in front of me.

-But really just to remember
those who died in the attacks

of 9/11, and the responders
he met with today, who he

obviously spent lot of time
thanking them for their
service.

-One of those those left
over [INAUDIBLE].
[LAUGHTER]
-Thank you, guys.
God bless you.
Appreciate it.
Proud of you.

Keep up the great
work, all right?

-It brings back a lot of
memories, obviously, because I

think really the last time I
was at Ground Zero was when
President Bush was here.

That was a day that I'll
never forget either.

When President Bush came, there
was a lot of emotion

about what had happened
and how tragic it was.

President Bush climbed up on
rubble of a fire truck and

told all the people that were
listening, that they will hear

us, and we will not
forget this.

And President Obama reiterated
that today, saying to the

first responders here that
America will not forget, and

we haven't forgotten, and
justice was done by killing
Osama bin Laden.

Obviously, visually riding into
Ground Zero today was

much different than the
last time I was here.

Today is a beautiful, bright,
sunny day, flags flying.

All the glass in those buildings
that were out before
have all been replaced.

Obviously, the Twin Towers
are being rebuilt.

It's a far different scene from
the last time I was here.

-This is Ben Carey of
the New York Times.

When the news came out about
Osama bin Laden's death last

Sunday, celebrations erupted in
Washington, D.C., New York,
and across the country.
[CROWD CELEBRATION]

-The reaction to these
celebrations was mixed.

Many people wanted
to join in them.
[CROWD CELEBRATION]

-Others were appalled and felt
that it was unseemly.
[CROWD CELEBRATION]

-And doesn't this make us look
like the terrorists, that
we're celebrating a death.
[CROWD CELEBRATION]

-I've been speaking with
psychologists and other social

scientists, who study revenge
and forgiveness, and they

describe the reaction as a
natural one, very human.

Some of the reasons for
this are obvious.

For one, it was clear victory
for the United States, another

clear example of justice
being done with
consequences delivered.

And there was a PR value
certainly in the killing.

But there are other factors
at work as well.

For one, a lot of the people on
the streets were younger,

and they've grown up under the
shadow of terrorism, in

particular, this terrorist. And
for them, it was a kind of

existential release, a release
of anxiety that this cloud had
been removed quite suddenly.

-I have friends with parents
dead because of Osama bin
Laden's plan, OK?

So when I heard this
news, I was coming
down here to celebrate.

-Some researchers say that part
of the reason for the

emotion is that this was
a fait accompli.
He was gone.

He wasn't brought back to
trial, but that he was

captured and killed,
and it was over.

Another factor is that terrorism
and 9/11, in

particular, reminds people
of their own mortality.

And psychologists who study
that effect find that when

that happens, people
become more tribal.

People who are patriotic become
very much more so.

People who are religious
become more so.

And in a crowd situation,
they feed on each other.

Ultimately, social scientists
say it's better to try to

understand human behavior than
to judge it prematurely.

Revenge is a very intrinsic
appetite in human cultures.

It goes way back in evolution,
and it's there for a reason.

It's there so that people can
see the cost of acting badly,

in a way to reach into the
heads of others who are
contemplating similar action.

So in that way, the
celebrations, as frivolous as

they might have seemed or even
as indecent to some, send a

very serious, primitive,
psychological message to other

terrorists that there
is a cost to
attacking the United States.
